entries.author: anirvan_chatterjee
entries.text: Anirvan tried what he thinks is invalid markdown with four different markdown modules, and as a result suggests that Text::Markdown::Discount may be a good choice. One of the problems with markdown is that there are a lot of things not covered by the official spec (which is what prompted Common Mark, amongst other things).
entries.title: Picking a better Markdown library for bad input

entries.text: Pastel de Nata is a Portuguese egg tart pastry. If you haven't tried one, you should try and track some down, because done well, they're delicious. I'm pretty sure 8 out of 10 P5P participants would agree with me.

entries.text: G’day, Perl Mongers of Australia! Do you have a strong background in Perl, but a desire to learn and apply other languages? This client is looking for a polyglot developer, with a focus on Perl but potential to also use (and be cross-trained in) Scala, Ruby, Python and JavaScript. It is a small, flexible team and there may be the opportunity to undertake some DevOps work too if interested.
entries.title: Polyglot required Down Under – Senior Developer role in Melbourne, Australia

entries.text: The Victorian poet Matthew Arnold called Oxford ‘the city of dreaming spires’, and even the most unromantic among us would surely agree there is something magical about Oxford on a misty autumnal morning.
entries.title: Dreaming of Perl? Mid/Senior-level developer role in The City of Dreaming Spires

entries.text: Friendly and quiet office in London (W1) looking for a Perl (or similar) developer with at least two years experience. You’re expected to have fullstack experience/abilities, from improvements on the client’s HTML front-end to backend services. It’s a small company, so there’s some fluidility expected between roles - a good place to expand on your jack-of-all-software-trades skillset.
entries.title: Science background, or a passing interest in life sciences? Junior/mid-level Perl developer needed in London...

header:
Two of this week's entries are about tools that people wrote to scratch their own itch.
That's always been one of the reasons I like Perl: it seems to encourage you to scratch your own itch.
What itch have you scratched recently? Why not tell us about it.
subject: Scratching your itch
